quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Anneka shares a ton of powerful advice on navigating difficult personalities, giving and hearing hard feedback, bringing humor and gratitude to every situation, managing your energy versus managing your time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A compact preview of several actionable themes, including the counterintuitive shift from time management to energy management.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Super tactical tips for how to become more strategic and how to make better decisions, and also how to break into product management for people that are trying to become product managers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights practical, practitioner-oriented takeaways on strategy, decision-making, and entering PM roles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So, I want to start with a question that I've started to ask guests that come on the podcast that have had extraordinarily successful careers and also just consistently successful careers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets up a repeatable interview framework focused on extracting transferable success patterns.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What do you believe are one or two skills or mindsets or habits that you think most contributed to your success that you think might be helpful for other people to learn and build to help them have more successful careers?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A direct prompt that encourages identifying the highest-leverage, broadly applicable career inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Having fun during hard times at work
quotes.text: My one mindset that I really have leaned into after someone actually gave me advice on this is to figure out how to have fun in my job, even in the most difficult of times.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable mindset shift for staying effective under pressure instead of getting stuck in stress.

quotes.topic_title: Having fun during hard times at work
quotes.text: The reason why I say that is because when you're hit with really hard times, it's easy to operate from a mindset of scarcity and to look at everything as an unachievable hurdle to overcome.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Names the failure mode (scarcity thinking) that her “have fun” approach is designed to counteract.

quotes.topic_title: Having fun during hard times at work
quotes.text: This advice specifically came up to me when I had a scenario where I had to essentially change out all of my direct reports in very short order, and I figured that out.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A concrete example showing the mindset is meant for genuinely hard leadership situations, not just minor stressors.

quotes.topic_title: Having fun during hard times at work
quotes.text: One is figure out and really look at the situation and ask myself, what can I learn from this situation? What can I get out of this that's a positive outcome even though it is incredibly challenging to be facing it right now?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: An actionable reframing prompt practitioners can use immediately to find leverage in difficult moments.

quotes.topic_title: Having fun during hard times at work
quotes.text: Being able to manage my energy levels and figuring out how to schedule my time for my energy has really allowed me also to figure out how to have that abundant mindset in all situations.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Connects “mindset” to a practical operating system: energy management and scheduling for peak performance.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're a founder, exec, product manager or engineer tasked with the enterprise roadmap, this conference is for you.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Clear targeting advice for practitioners responsible for enterprise product strategy and roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Topics included advanced identity management, compliance, encryption, and logging essentially at complex features that most enterprise customers require.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of enterprise-grade capabilities teams can use to pressure-test their roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The AI support agent can deflect upwards of 80% of support questions providing actually useful answers, and it can magically co-browse with your users to show them around your interface.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific performance claim plus a tactical capability (co-browsing) that suggests how to scale support and onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They do pop-ups too, but their nudges are based on in-product behaviors like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A behavior-triggered nudge model that reframes pop-ups as context-aware interventions rather than generic interruptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And he had some really interesting takes on ways to think about founder mode, both from product leader perspective, from a founder perspective.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a dual-lens mental model for evaluating “founder mode” from both leadership and founder viewpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode: working effectively with founders
quotes.text: Now I think the way to use that effectively as a head of product is to recognize that they have that power to figure out how to use that power to get the things done that you know are best for the company.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat the founder’s authority as a force-multiplier you can deliberately deploy for company priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode: working effectively with founders
quotes.text: So, I always think about I have all the people around me. Whether they're people on my team, my peers, or my CEO, these are different resources I have to go get a initiative done or get work done in the company.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Reframes leadership as resource orchestration—explicitly including the CEO/founder as an execution resource.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode: working effectively with founders
quotes.text: And so activating that founder, that CEO to really be able to push the initiative that I think is best by making them an ally in doing so.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Actionable advice: proactively enlist the founder as an ally to drive change rather than treating them as a blocker.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode: working effectively with founders
quotes.text: So, one is actually taking a step back and objectively saying, "Well, why are they pushing this?"
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic move for “founder pet projects”: start by uncovering the underlying objective before debating solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode: working effectively with founders
quotes.text: Then you have to decide as a head of product, do I really want to fight this or do I just give in on this, let it go?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A pragmatic, counterintuitive stance: sometimes the right move is to concede on a pet project to protect focus on what matters most.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode as a product leader
quotes.text: What I've found is that understanding the details of the business and asking questions and understanding to the utmost extent you can, what's working, what's not, what are the financial goals of the business? Are we on track to get there? How are we making decisions? Getting into that level of depth is super important, and then you can decide as a leader, what do you want to do with that information?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A practical founder-mode principle: go deep on business/financial details first, then choose when (and whether) to act.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode as a product leader
quotes.text: That's my choice to make, but I want the information because in understanding the depth and what is happening, I can decide where I actually think I need to go in deep and make either very significant course correction or a small course correction.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A selective-intervention model: collect lots of signal, then intervene only where the correction size warrants it.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode as a product leader
quotes.text: One of the tactics I use is I ask people to present their strategies for things that I think we may need to do a course correction on, and I have them come in and then I ask them questions and then I make suggestion.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A repeatable tactic for course-correcting without demoralizing teams: have them present, then guide via questions and suggestions.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode as a product leader
quotes.text: I pick a strategic set of areas. So I think about what is most important for the business? What's going to kill the business if we don't get right and what are the biggest opportunities for the business that we need to go after regardless of how difficult it is for us to actually execute on that?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A prioritization framework that forces focus on existential risks and outsized opportunities, even when execution is hard.

quotes.topic_title: Founder mode as a product leader
quotes.text: It's also sharing a hypothesis. So I might have a particular hypothesis about the business where I might see something like, "Well, I was talking to security leaders in our customer advisory board recently and I heard this piece of feedback and this is what it made me think about our strategy, what do you think about that?"
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A concrete method for influencing strategy without shutting debate down: seed a hypothesis grounded in customer feedback and invite critique.

quotes.topic_title: Becoming more strategic: definition and tactics
quotes.text: I think when people say "I want someone that's strategic," what they're really saying is "I want someone that can come up with and articulate a compelling and simple why behind the decisions and the direction of the company and product."
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Defines “strategic” in a concrete, testable way: the ability to clearly articulate the why behind direction and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Becoming more strategic: definition and tactics
quotes.text: The second piece is, "I want someone that's going to champion and be a change agent to do things that may be hard but actually best for the long-term interest of the product or company, even though those things are not going to be easy to execute on."
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Adds the second half of the strategy definition: driving difficult long-term change, not just explaining it.

quotes.topic_title: Becoming more strategic: definition and tactics
quotes.text: And I think if you have one without the other, ultimately people are not going to see you as strategic.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Memorable “two-part formula” that challenges the idea that either vision or execution alone is enough to be seen as strategic.

quotes.topic_title: Becoming more strategic: definition and tactics
quotes.text: The first step that I found as very useful, and I use this tactic every single day in meetings, is just summarization.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Gives a simple, repeatable tactic practitioners can apply immediately to demonstrate strategic thinking in meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Becoming more strategic: definition and tactics
quotes.text: That summarization, even though I may not be adding a new idea into that, I found people actually view that as strategy. They view the effective summarization as strategy.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation: synthesizing others’ input (not inventing new ideas) can be perceived as strategic leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: be the historian of past choices
quotes.text: So one of the things that I decided to do when I joined the company was to really understand what happened in the past.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable practice for new leaders: deliberately study prior decisions to improve current decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: be the historian of past choices
quotes.text: I tried to construct this past knowledge of what had happened and what were the decisions that were made and why were those decisions made, whether they were good or bad it didn't matter, so that I could better understand how to make decisions going forward and to learn from the mistakes that I didn't personally live through.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A “decision historian” framework: reconstruct decision rationale without judgment to learn from failures you didn’t experience firsthand.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: be the historian of past choices
quotes.text: You can always be a historian.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Reframes the approach as an ongoing leadership habit, not just onboarding work.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: be the historian of past choices
quotes.text: And also, what is the baggage that people have around trying to do something similar again?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: Highlights a practical diagnostic: uncover emotional/organizational “baggage” that will shape stakeholder reactions to new initiatives.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: be the historian of past choices
quotes.text: And some people are going to come and say, "Well, we've tried that before."
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A predictable objection you can anticipate and preempt by knowing the company’s decision history.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: commit, learn, and iterate fast
quotes.text: But the reality is that you were always operating off of imprecise information as a product leader.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A grounding mental model that reframes uncertainty as the default state, reducing the urge to wait for perfect data.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: commit, learn, and iterate fast
quotes.text: And as long as your decision is like 70% right, you can iterate on that 20, 30% in either direction, but if you don't commit, then you don't actually get any new information that is high fidelity and high quality.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A practical decision threshold (70% confidence) that emphasizes commitment as the gateway to high-quality learning.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: commit, learn, and iterate fast
quotes.text: Just make a decision. Don't make it uninformed, but have a strong hypothesis and then just keep testing whether that hypothesis is accurate or not and you'll shift here and there.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A repeatable operating method: decide with a hypothesis, then iterate via continuous validation.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: commit, learn, and iterate fast
quotes.text: I think the way to make a culture of risk taking and people willing to make these bets and go out on a limb is to reward the learning versus the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A culture design principle that reduces fear of being wrong by shifting incentives from results to learning.

quotes.topic_title: Decision-making: commit, learn, and iterate fast
quotes.text: And so now I think now what I've taken from that is really know how you're going to sell something and who's going to do the selling before you actually go build out the product.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A concrete pre-build checklist item that prevents building great products that fail due to missing go-to-market ownership.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear principle for product and growth teams on why investing in experimentation matters.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the dual goal of moving faster without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most was our experimentation platform where I could set up experiments, easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of self-serve experimentation as a productivity unlock for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable loop (“A/B testing flywheel”) where sharing insights generates more experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Check out Eppo at geteppo.com/Lenny and 10X your experiment velocity.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific, memorable claim about the magnitude of impact focused on experimentation speed.

quotes.topic_title: Navigating difficult personalities with curiosity and gratitude
quotes.text: I try to embody the mindset of feeling like and believing that I can work with anyone.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A foundational mindset shift that sets the tone for handling difficult personalities proactively rather than defensively.

quotes.topic_title: Navigating difficult personalities with curiosity and gratitude
quotes.text: I really try to understand what drives that person. What is it that they really care about?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question for uncovering motivations so you can align incentives and collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Navigating difficult personalities with curiosity and gratitude
quotes.text: I just need to understand what it is that they really care about, and then if I need something from them, what is it that I can do to motivate them to find what I need from them important?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: An actionable method for influencing hard-to-work-with colleagues by connecting your needs to their incentives.

quotes.topic_title: Navigating difficult personalities with curiosity and gratitude
quotes.text: The other thing I do is instead of feeling like anger or frustration with the person and instead trying to shift that to a mindset of feeling gratitude and a positive emotion about them is I look at them and I ask myself what can I learn?
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive emotional reframe that turns interpersonal friction into learning and reduces unproductive conflict.

quotes.topic_title: Navigating difficult personalities with curiosity and gratitude
quotes.text: Talk to other people that have worked with them before and have done so successfully.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for quickly learning how to work with a difficult person by leveraging others’ experience.

quotes.topic_title: Receiving hard feedback: feel it, then get curious
quotes.text: And I try to let myself just feel the things that I'm going to feel.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A simple first step for receiving hard feedback: allow the emotional reaction instead of suppressing it.

quotes.topic_title: Receiving hard feedback: feel it, then get curious
quotes.text: Then once that's passed, whether that's a few hours or a few days, don't react. Don't try to say, "Oh, I don't believe this." Listen.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A practical rule to prevent defensiveness: delay response until emotions subside, then focus on listening.

quotes.topic_title: Receiving hard feedback: feel it, then get curious
quotes.text: Actually, all feedback I think is valid. People's feelings are valid, but it doesn't mean that you need to do something about all of those things.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A counterintuitive distinction that helps leaders acknowledge feedback without overcorrecting or trying to please everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Receiving hard feedback: feel it, then get curious
quotes.text: I always try to anchor on, "Well, what is best for the company and what does the company need for me and for my team at this point in time?"
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic for deciding which feedback to act on based on current company needs.

quotes.topic_title: Receiving hard feedback: feel it, then get curious
quotes.text: I think when you come back curious, people then want to give you more feedback because they know that you're listening and that you're hearing what they say.
quotes.speaker: Anneka Gupta
quotes.context: A behavioral insight: curiosity increases future feedback flow by signaling psychological safety and genuine listening.
